title: THREE CENTRAL AMERICAN BAT COMMUNITIES: STRUCTURE, REPRODUCTIVE CYCLES, AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS'

body_text.text: Panama Canal Zone and one locality in western Costa Rica. Removal sampling and banding techniques using Japanese mist nets were employed to document community structure, food habits, reproductive cycles, and movement patterns of these bats.

Results indicated that 27-31 species occur at or near ground level at each locality. Species diversity, as measured by H', was highest in the Costan Rican community; each community contained 3-4 common species and many uncommon species. Based on body size and general food habits, niche overlap appears to be greatest among small to intermediate-sized insectivores and frugivores, many of which, however, are apparently uncommon. Four basic reproductive patterns are found among the species. Most frugivores are seasonally polyestrous whereas some insectivores are monestrous and at least one is polyestrous. It is postulated that in both insectivores and frugivores birth peaks coincide with maximum food levels. Recapture patterns of several species suggest that home range size may be positively correlated with body size; omnivorous species may have larger home ranges than similarly sized species with more restricted diets.

Compared with temperate North and South America, the New World tropics has a large and ecologically diverse bat fauna. For example, Barbour and Davis (1969) list 40 species of bats from continental North America north of Mexico (about 7,400,000 kM2), whereas Handley (1966) Two recent studies of neotropical bat faunas (Tamsitt 1967 , McNab 1971 have led to interesting speculations about how species partition resources so I Received November 15, 1971; accepted March 8, 1972. as to maintain high diversity of species. Each paper points to the need for detailed knowledge of the structure of bat faunas at the community level, and particularly of the roles of interacting species. The present study, designed to obtain such data, is based upon fieldwork covering 2 years (June 1966 through May 1967 and August 1970 through August 1971 at two localities in the Panama Canal Zone and one locality in Costa Rica . As with Tamsitt's and McNab's work, this study can be criticized as giving a biased account of bat community structure because of the techniques used, but we believe it represents a reasonable start toward an understanding of bat communities in the New World tropics.

Three sites located in two contrasting climatic zones were chosen for study: Rodman Naval Ammunition Depot (8?57' N, 79?37' W) , 8 km W Balboa, C. Z.; Fort Sherman Military Reservation (9?20' N, 79?57' W) , 3 km W Cristobal, C. Z.;
This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:30:01 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms (Holdridge and Budowski 1956, Holdridge 1967) .

Climatic characteristics of the three localities are summarized in Table 1 through April in the Canal Zone. Of the three sites, Fort Sherman receives the most rain annually and La Pacifica the least (Table 1) , Peak months of rainfall at La Pacifica are June and September-October and October-November in the Canal Zone ( Fig. 1) .

At Rodman and Fort Sherman several different habitats were sampled at various times during the year. These included riparian, swamp, and second growth forests and, at Fort Sherman, several cativals, forests dominated by nearly pure stands of cativo trees (Prioria copeifera). Preliminary analysis of the bat samples from the different habitats at each locality revealed that similar degrees of within-and between-habitat faunal overlap (as determined using Horn's (1966) index of ecological overlap) obtained so that all data were pooled at each site. Because of the widespread destruction of natural vegetation at La Pacifica, only riparian forest was sampled there.
Details of the vegetation of the three sites are presented elsewhere (Fleming 1971b, Rockwood, un- published thesis).

All bats examined in this study were captured in Japanese mist nets (usually 12 m long by 2 m high) set to extend from ground level beside and across streams and in forest clearings. Because previous studies (Brown 1968 , LaVal 1970 have indicated that peaks in bat activity often occur early in the evening, nets were usually opened from dusk (1800-1830) until 2100-2200. Because only one level of the forest was sampled during part of the night and because species of bats are caught unequally by mist nets, the following analysis of community structure undoubtedly represents a biased picture of the actual structure of tropical bat communities. Conspicuously missing from the samples are members of the strictly insectivorous families Emballonuridae, Vespertilionidae, and Molossidae, bats that are either adept at avoiding mist nets or that probably forage at heights above mist nets set at ground level. Netting at different heights throughout the night, as Handley (1967) did in Brazil, would undoubtedly have increased the number of species at each locality and made possible comparisons of relative abundance of species at different levels of the forest.

Bats from the Panama localities were killed soon after capture, but all Costa Rican bats were banded, examined, and released at the site of capture. Data recorded for the banded bats included species, sex, age (immature or adult based on the degree of closure of the phalangeal epiphyses; the immature class included bats from weaning (1 month of age) to 3-4 months), and reproductive condition. For males, location of testes (abdominal or scrotal) was recorded, but because testis position is apparently labile in many species, little confidence can be placed in this character as an indication of reproductive state. Females were palpated to determine the presence or absence of embryos (small embryos were undoubtedly missed by this technique), and the condition of the nipples (not evident, lactating, or postlactating) was recorded.

Many of the Costa Rican bats were "dusted" with a sticky gel to collect pollen, and seeds in their feces were collected for later identification. Results of the pollen and seed studies will be presented elsewhere.

All Panamanian bats collected were preserved in 10% formalin and later dissected in the laboratory for data on reproductive condition and stomach contents. In addition to the same data as recorded for This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:30:01 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms the Costa Rican bats, the following information was noted for each specimen. Greatest length of testis (mm) was employed to estimate the reproductive state of males. Additionally, a few testes and epididimydes were embedded in Tissuemat, serially sectioned at 10 V., and stained with Celestine Blue and eosin. The sections were examined for evidence of spermatogenesis and for spermatozoa in the epididymis. Females were examined for embryos, whose size was expressed as crown-rump length in millimeters. To check for microscopic evidence of pregnancy, the ovaries and uteri of many females were sectioned and stained as described above. Microscopic examination revealed that many early stages of pregnancy (i.e., embryos < 1 mm) were missed so that our estimates of frequency of pregnancy based only on macroscopic examination may be somewhat low.

Stomach contents of the Panamanian bats were placed in petri dishes, and the percentage by volume of plant and animal material estimated under a dissecting or compound microscope using magnifications of 7-150 X. Contents were designated as pollen, fruit pulp or seeds, insects, or animal flesh. Although seeds found in the stomachs were not identified, 25 kinds which appeared repeatedly were sufficiently distinct that a reference collection was established and the specimens containing these seeds listed. This collection, along with the other stomach contents, is available for further study.

We have followed Handley (1966) and Davis (1969) in the names employed for the bat species. Sets of externally similar congeners are fairly common in the areas of study and sometimes are not easily recognized. Of the several of these represented in the Panamanian samples, most are sufficiently well characterized such that we are reasonably certain of our identifications. We had considerable difficulty with Carollia, however, and were unable to positively identify specimens in the hand in Costa Rica or to interpret the variation seen in the preserved Panamanian collection in terms of the species represented, which possibly include C. castanea H. Allen, C. subrufa (Hahn), C. brevicauda (Wied), and C. perspicillata Linnaeus. Carollia castanea is easily recognizable, but we have not been able to sort satisfactorily the specimens of other species which the range of size variation suggests may be present. In the Panamanian series we see characters (for example, those of shape of upper toothrow and size of lower incisors) said to distinguish perspicillata, subrufa, and brevicauda (Handley 1966 , Pine 1968 ), but those characters do not seem to sort out in any meaningful way. We have, therefore, left them together as one lot under the name Carollia "perspicillata" and point out the possibility that more than one species may be represented.

The number of species and individuals captured at each locality are summarized in Greatest occupancy is observed in the 35-to 43-mm fruit-eating cell (Table 4 ). There are six to eight species in this cell in each community. Of these species, however, only one or two can be considered "common" (represented by more than 100 specimens in our collections). At Sherman, Carollia "perspicillata" and Uroderma bilobatum are the two abundant frugivores of similar size. At La Pacifica, C. (Table   5 ). Although part of this difference may result from the relatively slow passage of chitinous insect parts through stomachs as compared with the relatively rapid passage of fruit pulp and seeds, another part very likely reflects differences in the times of feeding of insectivorous and frugivorous forms, as suggested by Brown (1968) .

body_text.text: All sampled species of the Emballonuridae, Vespertilionidae, and Molossidae were wholly insectivorous ( are also known to be carnivorous (Dunn 1933 , Goodwin and Greenhall 1961 , Walker 1964 . Food habits of Micronycteris hirsute in Panama yary seasonally;

in the dry season this species feeds primarily on fruit and switches to insects in the wet season (Wilson 1971 , 3, 4, 6, 12, 15, 17, 20, 22, 23 C. "perspicillata" All except 8, 22, 24 Uroderma bilobatum 2, 4, 7, 8, 9, 11 Vampyrops helleri 7 Artibeus watsoni 7 A. jamaicensis 7, 8, 9, 24 A. lituratus 7, 20 pyressa, and Artibeus) are primarily frugivorous, though most species also consume insects ( Table 5) .

Although sample sizes are small, seasonal differences in food habits were not evident in G. soricina, Carollia "perspicillata," and C. castanea (Fig. 3) . In G. soricina, insect remains made up a substantial portion of the stomach contents in most months; pollen was recorded in February, March, and November, the first 2 months being a peak in the flowering season in central Panama (Croat 1970) . Stomachs of C. "perspicillata" contained predominantly fruit pulp and seeds throughout the year (Fig. 3) species; such differences have also been noted in several of the same species in Brazil (Carvalho 1961 ). The diets of both "species" of Carollia appear to overlap to a considerable extent; 8 of 10 kinds of seeds found in stomachs of C. castanea were also found in stomachs of C. "perspicillata." Quantitative as well as qualitative differences in the diets of the 12 species may also exist but could not be documented in this study. Further, because the number of different seeds eaten by each species was significantly correlated with the number of stomachs containing seeds (r = 0.95; P < .01), we can say nothing about the relative breadth of the food niches of the bats examined in this study.

Year-round activity.-Based on a small sample, Wimsatt and Trapido (1952) . Three weeks to 2 months (4 months for the Tenerito site) elapsed between visits to each station. Five to 10 nets were run for 1 or 2 consecutive nights each time a site was visited; nets were placed parallel to the rivers (sites 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8) or diagonally across narrow river channels (sites 5, 7, and 8) ( Between August 19, 1970, and August 14, 1971, 964 bats of 27 species were banded. One hundred bats of 10 species (37% of the species and 10.5%

of the individuals banded) were recaptured a total of 135 times (Table 8) Movements between virtually all the netting sites along the Corobici were recorded for the six most frequently recaptured species. This suggests that these species are regularly using the river system and surrounding riparian forest as some combination of flyways, feeding grounds, and possibly roosting sites.

In contrast, no movements were recorded between the Tenerito site and any of the Corobici sites. Although the Tenerito location was sampled only four times and only 109 bats were marked there, these results suggest that relatively little interchange occurs between the bats utilizing the two river systems.
Disregarding the one recorded movement of 1,620 m for an individual of Noctilio leporinus (a fisheating bat), mean distance between successive recaptures in eight species ranged from 167 m for C.

"perspicillata" to 400 m for Phyllostomus discolor (Table 8 ). "perspicillata," S. lilium, and D. rotundus. Because of the small area covered by the banding stations, nothing can be said about the actual home range size of any of the species, although recapture distances of nearly 2 km along the Corobici suggest that some species range over a wide area between roosting and feeding sites each night.
The data on proportion of individuals recaptured (Table 8 ) also support the contention that some species have significantly larger home ranges than others.

If, as seems reasonable, the probability of an individual being recaptured is inversely related to the difference between its home range size and the area covered by the netting sites, then recapture proportions should be inversely related to mean recapture distance (an index of home range size). This is the case (r = -0.786; P < .05). We therefore conclude that several species (i.e., A. jamaicensis, A. lituratus, G. soricina, and P. discolor) have relatively large ranges and/ or are nomadic whereas several other species (i.e., C. "perspicillata," S. lilium, Artibeus phaeotis, and D. rotundus) have relatively small ranges and tend to be sedentary.

The recapture of several bats banded at La Pacifica in July 1968 by R. K. LaVal (Table 8) Handley (1966) . Since the distribution of these two characters did not differ significantly from "expected" distributions based on the entire Panamanian bat fauna (P > .05) in Kolmogorov-Smirnov one-sample tests), we tentatively conclude that if competition has been a major factor in determining the structure of these bat communities, it has not acted by selectively favoring or eliminating body sizes and food habits as they occur in the Panamanian bat "universe." Hypothesis (2) predicts that single occupancy of cells of a "niche matrix" should be the rule. As seen in Table 4 , construction of a two-dimensional "niche matrix" is sufficient to separate most "large" species, but not the "small" species. Apparently, increased dimensionality of the "niche matrix" is needed to distinguish ecologically the small to intermediate-sized insectivores and frugivores in each community; additional dimensions might include principal foraging heights (and times?) and a finer breakdown of the kinds of fruit or prey items taken. Since, to judge from numbers captured at ground level (which are probably biased toward underestimating true abundances), many of the comparably sized species appear to be uncommon, competition among them for limited resources may not be severe during most of the year. Since it appears that food availability does vary seasonally in the habitats examined (see below), however, competition may increase at certain times of the year among small insectivores and small frugivores. Hutchinson (1959) . In determining the ratios of their trophic appendage, forearm lengths were substituted for skull lengths because the former measurement is easily obtained and is highly correlated (P < .01) with length of upper toothrow, perhaps a better indicator of "trophic apparatus" than skull length. The mean forearm ratio of the entire group was 1.26 (Table 9) , which is close to the average value of 1.28 observed by Hutchinson (1959) . Intrageneric ratios, however, were usually lower, and ratios of 1.20 or less were found in every genus except Phyllostomus (Table 9 ).

In Panama, the greatest number of sympatric con- In Panama and possibly Costa Rica, frugivorous bats producing young in the middle of the dry season are doing so just after one fruiting peak and just before another (Fig. 9) . Likewise, females carrying embryos in May and June and giving birth in July or August are doing so when fruit is relatively abundant. Although Smythe (1970) was sampling a relatively small number of fruit species (26), his data are probably indicative of the general situation in Panama (also see Croat 1970 ) so that the hypothesis that frugivores are producing young when food levels are high seems tenable. However, whereas young produced during the first parturient period become independent (about 1 month after birth) when fruit levels are relatively high, those born in the second period become independent when the abundance of fruit may be declining (Fig. 9) . Consequences of these declines on young and adults need to be further Smythe (1970) . See text for examples of "large" and "small" fruits. species, with the exception of M. nigricans, produce their young between March and August (Fig. 9) ; M. nigricans produces young through early November.

As indicated in Fig. 4 and 5, there is considerable intra-and interspecific synchrony in the reproductive cycles of many species and one wonders what environmental cue(s) is responsible for regulating these cycles. In Panama, many of the seasonally breeding species appear to initiate breeding again, after a quiescent period, between October and early December, at or just after the annual peak in rainfall and when daylength is decreasing. The fact that in western Costa Rica, where the dry season begins somewhat earlier, some of the same species begin breeding about 1 month earlier than in the Canal Zone suggests that decreasing amounts of rainfall, rather than photoperiod, may act as a proximate factor for several species. In at least one species, Myotis nigricans, photoperiod is the suspected environmental cue (Wilson and Findley 1970) . Clearly, we need experimental data to identify the specific factor(s) that regulates seasonal reproductive activity in tropical bats.

There are few data on movement patterns of neotropical bats. Williams and Williams (1967) and Wilson (1970) indicate that at least two species Our banding results support Laval's conclusions for each species except P. discolor, which we consider to have a large home range. This difference in results probably stems from the fact that LaVal captured most of his P. discolor in a banana grove adjacent to riparian forest whereas we netted only in riparian forest; the banana grove has been cut down. As La-Val noted, P. discolor is common in banana groves (for example, at Rodman we captured this species only in a small grove) so that if individuals return to the same grove to feed night after night, the probability of recapturing them should be high. Thus, netting only in banana groves could lead to erroneous conclusions regarding home range sizes of this species.

Our few recaptures suggest there may be a relationship between home range size and body size and, perhaps, food habits among tropical bats. Those species (i.e., A. jamaicensis, A. lituratus, P. discolor, and G. soricina), which we postulate as having large ranges are either large (the first three species) or omnivorous (the latter two species). back_matter.text: The Panamanian portion of this study was part of the Smithsonian Institution's Mammals of Panama Project and was supported in part by an NSF grant to Charles 0. Handley, Jr. We thank Dr. Handley for permission to report on the Panamanian specimens. Several agencies, including the Middle America Research Unit and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, provided valuable support for field work in the Canal Zone. George Barrett, Jr., was Fleming's field assistant in the Canal Zone.Research in Costa Rica was conducted under the auspices of the Organization for Tropical Studies. We thank Sr. Jorge Campabadal and his staff for their enthusiastic support and the Werner Hagnauers for their kind hospitality and permission to work at La Pacifica.Field assistance in Costa Rica was provided by Orlando Barboza, Robert Pitler, and Jeff Soleau; Ray Heithaus and Paul Opler also offered their enthusiastic help on many occasions. Technical assistance in the laboratory was provided by Jane Walker, Thomas White, and Marcia Fleming.Financial support for this project was supplied in part by NSF grants G-6379, GB-5801, and GB-21439 to Hooper; GB-21327 to Fleming; and GB-25189 to D. FIGREF0.text: records 102 species of bats from the Republic of Panama (77,100 kM2). Most temperate bats are entirely insectivorous. Tropical bats occupy a variety of food niches and include species that are frugivorous, nectarivorous, carnivorous, sanguinivorous, or piscivorous as well as species that are insectivorus. Since bats may comprise nearly one-half of the total number of mammalian species at specific localities in Panama and Costa Rica, they are important members of tropical communities, but little is presently known of their community ecology.

FIGREF1.text: and Fig. 1. Mean monthly temperature is similar in each area and averages about 270 C. At each locality rainfall is seasonal with the dry season lasting from mid-November through April at La Pacifica and from January

FIGREF3.text: common" species as defined in the text. four to five insectivores that occupy the 35-45 mm cell at Rodman and Sherman probably differ significantly in their spatial distributions: the two or three species of Micronycteris, all apparently uncommon (Handley 1966), forage within the forest whereas the one or two species of Molossus probably forage at higher levels. At La Pacifica, none of the five 35-43 mm insectivores, which include Rhynchonycteris naso, Micronycteris brachyotis, M. schmidtorum, M. megalotis, and Macrophyllum macrophyllum, appeared to be common there, and the different genera undoubtedly differ in their foraging locations and patterns.

FIGREF4.text: perspicillata" and Sturnira lilium are of comparable size and are abundant. How the niche requirements of these three species compare is presently unknown, but detailed studies of their food habits would probably reveal that these bats concentrate on different species of fruit.

The distribution of the 25 recognizable kinds of seeds in stomachs of 12 species of bats is presented in Table 6. Each seed type was found in 1-8 (mean = 2.2) species of bats, but 10 of the 25 kinds were found in a single species, suggesting that qualitative differences exist in the food preferences of the 12

FIGREF7.text: Reproductive conditions and embryo nancy are based on macroscopic examination only. Sample sizes are indicated above graphs. For A. jamaicensis, stippled areas indicate times when dormant embryos are found.This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:30:01 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms Reproductive conditions of adult females of three species of Costa Rican bats. Symbols as in Fig. 4. clearly indicate that two birth peaks occur annually in A rtibeus jamaicensis, Uroderma bilobatum, Sturnira lilium, Carol/ia "perspicillata," and Glossophaga .soricina in either or both Panama and Costa Rica. Though represented by smaller sample sizes, the following species also have bimodal birth periods in Panama: Artibeus lituratus, A. watsoni, A. phaeotis, Carol/ia castanea, and possibly Vampyrops he/leri and Chiroderma trinitatum(Table 7). In most of these, the first birth period (March or April) occurs in the second half of the dry season and the second (July or August) in the middle of the wet season.In western Costa Rica, where the dry season usually begins 1.5 months earlier than in the Canal Zone, birth periods of A. jamaicensis, C. "perspicillata"and Sturnira lilium occur in February, March, June, and July, somewhat earlier than in the Canal Zone.Both macroscopic and microscopic evidence indicates that females of several of the above species are polyestrous and undergo two pregnancies in rapid succession. One young is produced in each pregnancy. Macroscopic evidence includes numerous examples of females simultaneously pregnant and lactating in the period March through July in A. jamaicensis, U. bilobatum, and C. "perspicillata" in Panama. There is microscopic evidence for a postpartum estrus in A. jamaicensis (Fleming 1971a) and similar evidence is also available for U. bilobatum. If two pregnancies 12 Size of testis in three species of Panamanian bats. Diagrams indicate mean, range, and 2 SE in samples of five or more individuals. Dotted lines show testis length at or above which males are fertile. are the rule, annual productivity is two young per female in seasonally polyestrous phyllostomatids. Spermatogenic cycles of phyllostomatids, poorly known, appear to correlate with seasonal changes in female receptivity. In adults of A. jamaicensis, U. bilobatum, and C. "perspicillata," testis size is largest just preceding those times when females are likely to be sexually receptive ( in A . jamaicensis, July-August and March; in U. bilobatum, September-October and February-March, and in C. "perspicillata," October and March), and are smallest when females are unreceptive owing to pregnancy or seasonal sexual inactivity (Fig. 6). Owing to the seasonal periods of birth in many phyllostomatid bats, age structure of their populations varies seasonally. Figure 7, shows that in Panamanian populations of A. jamaicensis, U. bilobatum, and C. "perspicillata," immatures, which become independent of their mothers at about 1 month of age, are caught most frequently in the period April through October. A similar situation obtains in west-

FIGREF8.text: represent number pregnant/number examined. Embryo size in parentheses; lact = lactating. needed to more accurately determine the age at which sexual maturity is attained in A. jamaicensis and in other neotropical species. Among the seasonally polyestrous species, A. jamaicensis may be unique in that females in Panama apparently undergo a 2.5 month period of delayed embryonic development between September and mid-November (Fleming 1971a). Whether delayed development occurs in other Central and South American populations is not presently known. Females of other species of Artibeus and U. bilobatum and C. "perspicillata" in Panama were examined microscopically for evidence of delayed development, but, owing partly to the small samples available, the results were inconclusive. Available evidence does suggest, however, that C. "perspicillata" in Panama probably does not undergo delayed development. In summary, many frugivorous species in Panama and Costa Rica have two birth periods, one in the last half of the dry season and the other in the middle of the wet season. Females are po'yestrous and typically produce two young annually. Reproductive activity in males is correlated with periods of female receptivity. Extended season with a short inactive period.-Only one species, the insectivorous Myotis nigricans (Vespertilionidae), is known to have this pattern. In Panama, pregnant females are found from January through early November with individuals producing possibly three young (in three pregnancies) during that time (Wilson and Findley 1970). Spermatogenic activity in adult males declines in September through

Although individuals of 10 species were recaptured, four species, Carollia "perspicillata," Artibeus jamaicensis, Sturnira lilium, Bat-banding stations at Finca La Pacifica.Desmodus rotundus, provided the bulk of the recapture data. These four species differed significantly from each other in proportion of banded individuals that were recaptured, (X32 = 26.6; P < .001). Relatively few banded A. jamaicensis were recaptured (5.5%) compared with values of 16-20% for the other three species(Table 8). Also, no multiple captures of the same individual were recorded for A. jamaicensis, whereas several individuals of each of the other three species were recaptured up to four times in the year.

FIGREF13.text: indicates that at least some individuals of several species of tropical bats roost and forage in the same area for several years or more. Recaptures 2 to 3 years after banding were recorded for 12 individuals of six species: C. castanea (1), C. "perspicillata" (2), A. jamaicensis (1), S. lilium (2), G. soricina (2), and D. rotundus (4).

FIGREF14.text: of community structure operates to minimize competition among members of the same trophic level (i.e., to decrease ecological similarity between sympatric species), the distribution of body sizes and food habits among members might be ex-pected to (1) depart significantly from the distributions of these characters in the organisms' "universe" and (2) to allow species to occupy single cells in an n-dimensional "niche matrix." To test hypothesis (1), the data from Rodman and Sherman were compared with the distribution of body sizes and food habits in the bat fauna of Panama as listed by

FIGREF15.text: geners occurred in the genus Artibeus, in which three or four species of two size classes (medium-sized and large) occurred together. At Sherman two species occurred in each of the two size classes (Appendix 1). At La Pacifica, three species of Pteronotus and four species of Micronycteris were netted. Although the relatively low forearm ratios could be taken to indicate that the food niches of these tropical congeners overlap extensively (as concluded by Tamsitt 1967), the absence of detailed information concerning food habits, feeding behavior, and spatial distributions of the species precludes such a conclusion. Interspecific differences in any of the three unstudied factors could easily negate the possible effects of morphological similarity on degree of niche overlap. With our present knowledge, it is unwise to interpret metric similarities or dissimilarities in terms of "niche overlap." Reproduction and food habits The reproductive cycles of all organisms are presumably adapted so that offspring are produced at energetically favorable times of the year. Where food levels vary seasonally, seasonal reproductive cycles should be favored; where food levels remain fairly constant throughout the year, reproduction may be acyclic. The majority of Panamanian and Costa Rican bats examined in this study or reported on elsewhere have seasonal reproductive cycles; this suggests that they face seasonal shortages of food or other resources necessary for successful reproduction. Most frugivores produce two young annually, one toward the end of the dry season and another in the middle of the wet season. Insectivores tend to give birth in the wet season. The question then arises as to whether these birth periods coincide with peaks in the availability of fruit and insects. According to Janzen (1967), the dry season throughout much of Central America is the principal flowering season and the late dry and early wet seasons the principal fruiting season. Offering partial support for this generalization is the observation that the frequency of pollen-laden bats is higher in the dry season than in the wet season in Guanacaste (Heithaus and Fleming, unpublished). Further, in the Panama Canal Zone mangoes (Mangifera indica) and hog plums (Spondias mombin), known bat foods, are most abundant in April and May and in July through September, respectively; however, figs (Ficus insipida), a favorite of Artibeus jamaicensis, produce fruit sporadically throughout the year (Fleming 1971b). On Barro Colorado Island, midway between Rodman and Sherman, "large fruits" (e.g., Astrocaryum standleyanum, Oleicarpon panamense, and Anacardium excelsum) drop primarily in February, May, and June whereas "small fruits" (e.g., Cecro-This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:30:01 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms pia, Ficus, and Miconia) fall between May and November (Smythe 1970). The low point in the annual fruit cycle in central Panama appears to occur at the end of the wet season and early in the dry season (November through January).

FIGREF16.text: available concerning seasonal abundance of insects, especially those species eaten by bats, and the relationship of insect abundance to reproductive cycles of Central American bats. In Costa Rica, population levels of many insects are depressed in the dry season(Janzen 1967, Janzen andSchoener 1968), and are high from April to June(Skutch 1950). If the same situation holds in Panama, insectivorous and carnivorous species are probably producing young when their food levels are high(Fig. 9). Whether monestrous (e.g., Noctilio labialis, Pteronotus parnellii, and Saccopteryx bilineata) or polyestrous (e.g., Phyllostomus discolor, Trachops cirrhosus, and Myotis nigricans)Relationship between birth periods in 25 species of bats and monthly incidence of fruiting in the Panama Canal Zone. LaVal (1970) concluded from 6 nights of netting at La Pacifica in 1968 that Phyllostomus discolor and two species of Carollia have smaller home ranges than Artibeus jamaicensis, A. lituratus, and Glossophaga commissarisi.

note that in relatively undisturbed forest (Rodman
and Sherman) away from cattle-raising lands the
vampire bat, D. rotundus, is apparently uncommon,
in contrast to the situation in cattle-rich Guanacaste,
where it is abundant for obvious ecological reasons.

Food habits
Data on stomach contents of the Panamanian spec-
imens are summarized in Table 5. These data have
been augmented by the examination of the stomach
contents of 839 specimens of bats from several Costa
Rican localities; these are now housed in the Univer-
sity of Michigan Museum of Zoology's mammal col-
lection. Preliminary separate analyses of the Pan-
amanian and Costa Rican data failed to detect
significant geographic differences in the diets of spe-
cies common to both countries so that all data are
combined in the following account.
Because approximately 80% of the stomachs ex-
amined were empty, disappointingly little informa-
tion was obtained on food habits. Insectivorous
species were more generous in this respect than non-
insectivorous (fruit, pollen, blood, and fish-eating)
forms. Whereas an average of 63% of the individuals
of insectivorous species had full stomachs, the aver-

TABREF5.content:
). Of the two noctilionid species,
Noctilio labialis was insectivorous while N. leporinus
consumed both fish and insects. Whereas most spec-
imens of Pteronotus parnellii and P. suapurensis
(Mormoopidae) contained insects, two individuals of
the former species had seeds in their stomachs.
Our data indicate that members of the family Phyl-
lostomatidae eat a variety of food items. Species of
the subfamily Phyllostomatinae (Micronycteris, Lon-
chorhina, Tonatia, and Trachops) are primarily in-
sectivorous (Table 5); however, some phyllostoma-
tines (e.g., Phyllostomus hastatus, Trachops cirrho-
sus, Chrotopterus auritus, and Vampyrum spectrum)

TABREF8.text: , which include (I) seasonally monestrous,(2) seasonally polyestrous, (3) an extended season with a short period of reproductive inactivity, and (4) year-round activity, are described below.Seasonally monestrous.-This pattern has been previously demonstrated for the insectivorous Noctilio labialis (Noctilionidae) in Panama(Anderson and Wimsatt 1963). In this species copulations occur in late November or early December and young are born in late April or May. Our data(Table 7)sug-gest that at least one and possibly two other insectivorous species, Pteronotus parnellii (Mormoopidae) and Saccopteryx bilineata (Emballonuridae), are monestrous. The birth period in the former species apparently occurs in March or April, and in the latter in May or June. ~~~~~~~~~~~ . ............

appendages (bird culmens or mammal skulls) by a
factor of about 1.3. This size difference ostensibly
allows closely related species to exploit slightly dif-
ferent food niches, thereby permitting the species to
coexist. Lower ratios (1.0-1.2), however, have been
observed for tropical birds and bats (Klopfer and
MacArthur 1961, Tamsitt 1967) and have been in-
terpreted to indicate considerable niche overlap
among congeners.
Eight genera contained two or more sympatric
species in the two Panamanian communities and four
genera in the single Costa Rican community (Ap-
pendix 1)

TABREF16.text: This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:30:01 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms D. rotundus) which we postulate as having small ranges, are, except for D. rotundus, small to medium in size and are frugivorous (the first three species) or sanguinivorous. Thus, home range may be positively correlated with body size and, for a given body size, may be larger for omnivores than for species with more restricted diets. These generalizations, if valid, would seem to have important implications regarding the impact of different bat species as pollinating and seed dispersal agents in tropical ecosystems.
